title: A Way to Detect Bias
title_zh: [待翻译] A Way to Detect Bias

paragraphs: October 2015This will come as a surprise to a lot of people, but in some cases it's possible to detect bias in a selection process without knowing anything about the applicant pool. Which is exciting because among other things it means third parties can use this technique to detect bias whether those doing the selecting want them to or not.You can use this technique whenever (a) you have at least a random sample of the applicants that were selected, (b) their subsequent performance is measured, and (c) the groups of applicants you're comparing have roughly equal distribution of ability.How does it work?

Think about what it means to be biased. What it means for a selection process to be biased against applicants of type x is that it's harder for them to make it through. Which means applicants of type x have to be better to get selected than applicants not of type x.

[1] Which means applicants of type x who do make it through the selection process will outperform other successful applicants. And if the performance of all the successful applicants is measured, you'll know if they do.Of course, the test you use to measure performance must be a valid one.

And in particular it must not be invalidated by the bias you're trying to measure. But there are some domains where performance can be measured, and in those detecting bias is straightforward. Want to know if the selection process was biased against some type of applicant?

Check whether they outperform the others. This is not just a heuristic for detecting bias. It's what bias means.For example, many suspect that venture capital firms are biased against female founders.

This would be easy to detect: among their portfolio companies, do startups with female founders outperform those without? A couple months ago, one VC firm (almost certainly unintentionally) published a study showing bias of this type.

First Round Capital found that among its portfolio companies, startups with female founders outperformed those without by 63%. [2]The reason I began by saying that this technique would come as a surprise to many people is that we so rarely see analyses of this type.

I'm sure it will come as a surprise to First Round that they performed one. I doubt anyone there realized that by limiting their sample to their own portfolio, they were producing a study not of startup trends but of their own biases when selecting companies.I predict we'll see this technique used more in the future.

The information needed to conduct such studies is increasingly available. Data about who applies for things is usually closely guarded by the organizations selecting them, but nowadays data about who gets selected is often publicly available to anyone who takes the trouble to aggregate it.

Notes[1] This technique wouldn't work if the selection process looked for different things from different types of applicants—for example, if an employer hired men based on their ability but women based on their appearance.[2] As Paul Buchheit points out, First Round excluded their most successful investment, Uber, from the study.

And while it makes sense to exclude outliers from some types of studies, studies of returns from startup investing, which is all about hitting outliers, are not one of them. Thanks to Sam Altman, Jessica Livingston, and Geoff Ralston for reading drafts of this.Arabic TranslationSwedish Translation

2015年10月

这可能会让很多人感到惊讶，但在某些情况下，即使对申请者群体一无所知，也有可能检测出选择过程中的偏见。这非常令人振奋，因为这意味着第三方可以使用这种技术来检测偏见，无论那些做出选择的人是否愿意让他们这样做。你可以在以下情况下使用这种技术：(a) 你至少有一个被选中申请者的随机样本，(b) 他们的后续表现被衡量，以及 (c) 你正在比较的申请者群体在能力分布上大致相同。

这究竟是如何运作的？

paragraphs.original: Think about what it means to be biased. What it means for a selection process to be biased against applicants of type x is that it's harder for them to make it through. Which means applicants of type x have to be better to get selected than applicants not of type x.
paragraphs.translated: 思考一下偏见的含义。选择过程对某种类型的申请人存在偏见意味着他们更难通过这一过程。这意味着，这种类型的申请人必须比非这种类型的申请人更优秀才能被选中。

paragraphs.original: [1] Which means applicants of type x who do make it through the selection process will outperform other successful applicants. And if the performance of all the successful applicants is measured, you'll know if they do.Of course, the test you use to measure performance must be a valid one.
paragraphs.translated: 这意味着，通过选拔过程的X类申请者的表现将优于其他成功的申请者。如果对所有成功申请者的表现进行衡量，你就能知道他们是否真的表现更优。当然，你用来衡量表现的测试必须是有效的。

paragraphs.original: And in particular it must not be invalidated by the bias you're trying to measure. But there are some domains where performance can be measured, and in those detecting bias is straightforward. Want to know if the selection process was biased against some type of applicant?
paragraphs.translated: 特别是，它不应因你试图衡量的偏差而失效。但在某些领域，性能是可以衡量的，在这些领域中，检测偏差是 straightforward 的。想知道选择过程是否对某种类型的申请人存在偏见吗？

paragraphs.original: Check whether they outperform the others. This is not just a heuristic for detecting bias. It's what bias means.For example, many suspect that venture capital firms are biased against female founders.
paragraphs.translated: 检查它们是否优于其他。这不仅是检测偏见的一种启发式方法，这正是偏见的含义。例如，许多人怀疑风险投资公司对女性创始人存在偏见。

paragraphs.original: This would be easy to detect: among their portfolio companies, do startups with female founders outperform those without? A couple months ago, one VC firm (almost certainly unintentionally) published a study showing bias of this type.
paragraphs.translated: 这很容易检测：在他们的投资组合公司中，女性创始人领导的初创公司是否优于没有女性创始人的公司？几个月前，一家风投公司（几乎可以肯定是无意的）发布了一项研究，显示了这种偏见。

paragraphs.original: First Round Capital found that among its portfolio companies, startups with female founders outperformed those without by 63%. [2]The reason I began by saying that this technique would come as a surprise to many people is that we so rarely see analyses of this type.
paragraphs.translated: First Round Capital 发现，在其投资组合公司中，有女性创始人的初创公司表现比没有女性创始人的公司高出 63%。[2] 我之所以一开始就提到这种技术会让很多人感到意外，是因为我们很少看到这类分析。

paragraphs.original: I'm sure it will come as a surprise to First Round that they performed one. I doubt anyone there realized that by limiting their sample to their own portfolio, they were producing a study not of startup trends but of their own biases when selecting companies.I predict we'll see this technique used more in the future.
paragraphs.translated: 我相信，First Round 一定会对其研究结果感到惊讶。我怀疑他们那里没有人意识到，通过将样本限制在他们自己的投资组合中，他们实际上是在研究自己的选企偏见，而不是初创企业的趋势。我预测，未来我们将看到这种技术被更多地使用。

paragraphs.original: The information needed to conduct such studies is increasingly available. Data about who applies for things is usually closely guarded by the organizations selecting them, but nowadays data about who gets selected is often publicly available to anyone who takes the trouble to aggregate it.
paragraphs.translated: 进行此类研究所需的信息越来越容易获得。关于谁申请了某些职位的数据通常由负责选拔的组织严格保密，但如今，关于谁被选中的数据往往对任何愿意收集这些信息的人公开。

paragraphs.original: Notes[1] This technique wouldn't work if the selection process looked for different things from different types of applicants—for example, if an employer hired men based on their ability but women based on their appearance.[2] As Paul Buchheit points out, First Round excluded their most successful investment, Uber, from the study.
paragraphs.translated: 注释[1] 如果选拔过程中对不同类型申请者关注的方面不同，例如，雇主根据男性的能力但根据女性的外貌来雇佣，这种方法就不起作用。[2] 保罗·布赫伊特指出，第一轮资本将他们最成功的投资——优步，排除在了研究之外。

paragraphs.original: And while it makes sense to exclude outliers from some types of studies, studies of returns from startup investing, which is all about hitting outliers, are not one of them. paragraphs.translated: 虽然从某些类型的研究中排除异常值是合理的，但初创企业投资回报的研究并非如此，因为这项研究的核心正是寻找异常值。感谢 Sam Altman、Jessica Livingston 和 Geoff Ralston 阅读本文的草稿。阿拉伯语翻译瑞典语翻译
